net.cloud.gfx.handlers

Class KeyEventHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.event.KeyAdapter
      • net.cloud.gfx.handlers.KeyEventHandler
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.event.KeyListener, java.util.EventListener

    public class KeyEventHandler
extends java.awt.event.KeyAdapter
    This KeyAdapter will listen for key events in general and take events the Element hierarchy is interested in and pass them on to the object which currently has key focus in the system

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      KeyEventHandler()
      Create a KeyEventHandler which will hand the events it receives off to whatever Focusable which currently has key focus.

    • Method Summary

      Check to see if a character is ignored when it is typed.
      void keyPressed(java.awt.event.KeyEvent event)
      A KeyPressed event is fire for all keys, unlike key typed which is only fired for keys which correspond to a character.
      void keyTyped(java.awt.event.KeyEvent event)
      A KeyTyped event is what we're really after (key pressed and released are unlikely.) If the character is the NUL character or an undefined character was typed, this event will do nothing.

      Takes a key event from a KeyPressed event.

    • Constructor Detail

      • KeyEventHandler

        public KeyEventHandler()
        Create a KeyEventHandler which will hand the events it receives off to whatever Focusable which currently has key focus.

    • Method Detail

      • keyPressed

        public void keyPressed(java.awt.event.KeyEvent event)
        A KeyPressed event is fire for all keys, unlike key typed which is only fired for keys which correspond to a character. Since some of these events are interesting, we'll check them and see if they correspond to some artificial character constant we want to fire events for as well. Ultimately calls handleChar() when a key typed event would not.
        Specified by:
        keyPressed in interface java.awt.event.KeyListener
        Overrides:
        keyPressed in class java.awt.event.KeyAdapter
        Parameters:
        event - The KeyEvent

      • keyTyped

        public void keyTyped(java.awt.event.KeyEvent event)
        A KeyTyped event is what we're really after (key pressed and released are unlikely.) If the character is the NUL character or an undefined character was typed, this event will do nothing. Otherwise, the character will be passed to the Focusable that currently has focus.
        Specified by:
        keyTyped in interface java.awt.event.KeyListener
        Overrides:
        keyTyped in class java.awt.event.KeyAdapter

      • isIgnored

        private boolean isIgnored(char c)
        Check to see if a character is ignored when it is typed. Some characters it's just better to not let them even get into the application. They probably don't have any business being around, anyways. Ignored characters pretty much just aren't handled.
        Parameters:
        c - The character that was typed
        Returns:
        True if it should be ignored

      • mutateTypedKey

        private char mutateTypedKey(java.awt.event.KeyEvent event,
                            char c)
        Takes a key event from the KeyTyped event. For some typed keys, we want to change them into a different character based on factors like modifier keys. This method will check for this and return a character (defined in KeyConstants) for the special character.
        Parameters:
        event - The key typed event
        c - The character originally typed
        Returns:
        A special character constant from KeyConstants or the c parameter

      • mutatePressedKey

        private char mutatePressedKey(java.awt.event.KeyEvent event,
                              int keyCode)
        Takes a key event from a KeyPressed event. For events that do not trigger a key typed event as well, but we are still interested in handling. Takes the key code and maps it to a character constant.
        Parameters:
        event - The key event (for obtaining modifiers)
        keyCode - The key code from the event
        Returns:
        A character to handle if interested, null character if not

      • handleChar

        private void handleChar(char c)
        Passes the character onto whichever object currently has key focus in the system. If there is no such object, then nothing is done.
        Parameters:
        c - The character to fire an event for

      • currentIsModal

        private boolean currentIsModal()
        Assumes a check has been made and a modal dialog is present. Check to see if the current focused object is the modal dialog, or a child of the modal dialog. If the current focused object is not an Element, then this will simply return false.
        Returns:
        True if the currently focused object is within scope of the modal dialog
